senses.de: A piece of work that is carefully planned and designed with a specific purpose.
senses.ex: She's busy with a major project on climate change.

Tips.title: Long-term endeavors
Tips.description: Refers to tasks requiring considerable time and effort to complete.
Tips.example: He embarked on a project to write his first novel.

Tips.title: Collaborative nature
Tips.description: Often implies teamwork and collaboration towards common goals.
Tips.example: Our class project involved working in teams to create a documentary.

Tips.title: Outcome-focused
Tips.description: Emphasizes that the project has a clear end goal or result.
Tips.example: The community project aimed to build a new playground.

senses.de: To throw or cast something forward.
senses.ex: The machine projects the image onto a screen.

Tips.title: Visual representation
Tips.description: Involves making an internal concept visible externally.
Tips.example: The overhead projector was used to project the diagrams.

Tips.title: Larger display
Tips.description: Typically used to enlarge small images for a group to see.
Tips.example: The artist's projector could project the tiny sketch onto the large wall.

senses.de: To predict or estimate something in the future based on present data or trends.
senses.ex: Sales are projected to increase by 15% next year.

Tips.title: Future anticipation
Tips.description: Involves making informed guesses about what will happen later.
Tips.example: Based on current trends, we project a profit increase in Q4.

Tips.title: Data-driven
Tips.description: Requires analysis of data to make predictions.
Tips.example: The economist projected future economic downturns based on historical data.

senses.de: To make something visible or noticeable.
senses.ex: The castle is projected against the sky.

Tips.title: Perceptible impact
Tips.description: Pointing out something to make it easily seen or felt.
Tips.example: He knew how to project his voice across the crowded room.

Tips.title: Presence enhancement
Tips.description: Used to describe how one can seem larger or more noticeable.
Tips.example: Despite her small stature, she projected a commanding presence.

Tips.title: Confidence expression
Tips.description: Can convey a sense of confidence, even if not felt internally.
Tips.example: Projecting confidence during the interview is crucial.

senses.de: Unconsciously transfer one’s own feelings and thoughts to another person or object
senses.ex: She projects her own insecurities onto other people.

Tips.title: Emotional displacement
Tips.description: Involves attributing one's own emotions to others unintentionally.
Tips.example: He accused others of being angry, not realizing he projected his own anger.

Tips.title: Misunderstood behavior
Tips.description: Can be mistakenly thought of as someone else’s emotions or intentions.
Tips.example: Her tendency to project made it hard for her to recognize her own role in conflicts.

Assignment.wordDefinition:
An assignment is a task given to a person to complete within a specific time frame. Assignments are usually shorter than projects and are often given as a regular part of a course or program.

A project is a more complex and substantial assignment that requires planning, research, and execution over a longer period.

Both assignments and projects are used to measure someone's understanding of a specific topic or subject.

However, assignments are usually used more frequently in educational settings, while projects are used more often in professional or business environments.

Initiative.wordDefinition:
Initiative refers to a new idea or plan that someone takes the lead in starting.

An initiative is usually broader in scope than a project and often involves multiple projects.

Projects are usually created to achieve a specific goal or objective within a larger initiative.

Both initiative and project are applicable in various contexts, such as business, government, non-profits, and personal life.

Initiatives are typically more strategic and longer-term than projects, and projects are usually more tangible and shorter-term than initiatives.

For example, a company might launch an initiative to reduce its carbon footprint, and one of the projects within that initiative might be to install energy-efficient lighting in its offices.

Plan.wordDefinition:
A plan is a set of actions or steps that someone imagines or hopes to follow or take to achieve a goal or objective. It could be as simple as making a to-do list or as complex as a long-term strategy for a business or organization.

Plans are generally focused on achieving a specific outcome, and are often made beforehand.

Projects are often time-bound and require detailed planning and execution.

In summary, plans are general strategies or ideas, while projects are specific tasks or undertakings. Plans are applicable in situations where there is a need to set objectives or goals, while projects are applicable in situations where there is a need to carry out a specific set of tasks or activities to achieve those objectives or goals.

Programme.wordDefinition:
A program is a set of activities that are designed to achieve a specific goal or outcome over a period of time.

For example, a fitness program might involve different exercise routines, nutritional guidance, and lifestyle recommendations, all designed to help participants achieve overall health and wellness.

Both program and project management are important tools in achieving business objectives. Programs are best suited for achieving long-term goals, while projects are most beneficial for short-term objectives.

Program management may involve overseeing many projects that individually serve a particular purpose, while project management ensures a one-time goal is reached.

Proposal.wordDefinition:
A proposal is a suggestion or an idea that is presented to others for consideration, usually with the aim of persuading or convincing them to take action.

A proposal is often seen as the first step to making a project happen.

A project is the actual plan or idea that involves creating something, while a proposal is a document that presents a suggestion to achieve that plan or idea.

Scheme.wordDefinition:
Scheme refers to a plan or idea that is often associated with a level of deception or dishonesty.

A scheme is usually designed to benefit someone or a group of people in a way that is unfair or unethical.

For example, a fraudulent scheme involves scams or dishonest practices that are intended to deceive people and take their money.

A project is a well-planned and structured plan to achieve a specific goal while a scheme is a dishonest plan that involves deception or unfair practices.

Task.wordDefinition:
A project is a bigger and more complex assignment that involves multiple tasks and often requires a team to work on it.

A task is a smaller and more specific job that needs to be completed to achieve a specific goal. Tasks are usually a part of a project, and completing many tasks will eventually lead to the completion of the entire project.

For example, writing a report, designing a logo, or booking a venue are all examples of tasks.

A project is a broader and more complex goal that requires multiple tasks to be completed, while a task is a specific job that contributes to the completion of a project.

Undertake.wordDefinition:
Undertake means to agree to do something or to take on a particular responsibility or task.

It can be used in various contexts, such as in business or personal life. For instance, "I will undertake to complete the project by the end of the week.".

Project is more specific and refers to a defined task or goal, while undertake indicates taking on a responsibility or task.

Venture.wordDefinition:
A venture refers to a business or financial undertaking where there is an element of risk involved.

A venture is usually a new business or startup that requires investment or capital to get started.

A project is a task with a defined goal and timeframe, while a venture is a business or financial undertaking with an element of risk involved.

Projects are applicable to a wide range of fields, while ventures are primarily focused on entrepreneurship and business.

quotes.Text: A lot of times, people have something that they're afraid of. They've got a client that's mad at them. They've got a project that's due. And they let that stress hang over their head. I don't let that happen.
quotes.Title: American
quotes.Name: Jocko Willink

quotes.Text: I suffered from low self-esteem for much of my life. And now to feel like maybe something that I'm projecting or saying could mean something to someone means a lot to me.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Viola Davis

quotes.Text: I know movies are a function of our dream world. And when you project yourself on screen, it's easier to project yourself into what you were, not what you are.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Meryl Streep

quotes.Text: The truth is, anyone can start projects. The world is full of just-started projects that looked great at the time but were never completed.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Joyce Meyer

quotes.Text: Listening has importance only when one is not projecting one's own desires through which one listens.
quotes.Title: Indian Philosopher
quotes.Name: Jiddu Krishnamurti

quotes.Text: It takes half your life before you discover life is a do-it-yourself project.
quotes.Title: American Author
quotes.Name: Napoleon Hill

quotes.Text: My ultimate life dream project is my kids. My family.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Denzel Washington

quotes.Text: It's important in any project to remain focused.
quotes.Title: Egyptian Director
quotes.Name: Jehane Noujaim

quotes.Text: Living in the projects helped me with this role.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Joe Pantoliano

quotes.Text: Small projects need much more help than great.
quotes.Title: Italian Poet
quotes.Name: Dante Alighieri
